sn47.13:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn47.13:4.2: At that time Venerable Sāriputta was staying in the Magadhan lands near the little village of Nālaka, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn47.13:4.3: And the novice Cunda was his carer.
sn47.13:5.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta became finally extinguished because of that sickness.
sn47.13:5.2: Then Cunda took Sāriputta’s bowl and robes and set out for Sāvatthī. He went to see Venerable Ānanda at Jeta’s grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery,
sn47.13:5.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn47.13:5.5: “Sir, Venerable Sāriputta has become finally extinguished.
sn47.13:5.6: This is his bowl and robes.”
sn47.13:6.1: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
sn47.13:6.2: Come, let’s go to the Buddha
sn47.13:7.1: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha,
sn47.13:7.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn47.13:7.5: Venerable Sāriputta has become finally extinguished.
sn47.13:7.6: This is his bowl and robes.
sn47.13:7.7: Since I heard this, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, and teachings aren’t clear to me.”
sn47.13:8.1: “Well, Ānanda, when Sāriputta became finally extinguished, did he take away your entire spectrum of ethical conduct, of samādhi, of wisdom, of freedom, or of the knowledge and vision of freedom?”
sn47.13:8.6: But Venerable Sāriputta was my adviser and counselor. He educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired me. He never tired of teaching the Dhamma, and he supported his spiritual companions.
sn47.13:8.7: I remember the nectar of the teaching, the riches of the teaching, the support of the teaching given by Venerable Sāriputta.”
sn47.13:9.1: “But Ānanda, haven’t I already explained that
sn47.13:9.2: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?
sn47.13:9.4: what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to fall apart should not fall apart?
sn47.13:9.6: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood, and the largest branch fell off.
sn47.13:9.7: In the same way, in the great Saṅgha that stands with heartwood, Sāriputta has become finally extinguished.
sn47.13:9.9: what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to fall apart should not fall apart?
sn47.13:9.11: So Ānanda, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.13:10.1: And how does a mendicant do this?
sn47.13:10.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.13:10.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.13:10.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.13:10.6: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
sn47.13:10.7: Whether now or after I have passed, any mendicant who lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge:
sn47.13:10.8: they will be the best of those who want to train.”
